articles.headline: G.O.P. Race Starts in Lavish Haunts of Rich Donors
articles.snippet: In one resort town after another, the Republican presidential hopefuls are making their case to exclusive gatherings of donors whose wealth was unleashed by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision.
articles.abstract: In one resort town after another, the Republican presidential hopefuls are making their case to exclusive gatherings of donors whose wealth was unleashed by the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH, Fla. — Instead of the corn dogs and pork chops on a stick ritually served up on the hustings of Iowa, the latest stop on the donor trail featured meals of diver scallops and chocolate mousse. The setting was the Breakers, a sprawling Italian Renaissance-inspired hotel here, where the cheapest available rooms fetched $800 a night. And for the half-dozen Republican presidential candidates invited to the annual winter meeting this weekend of the Club for Growth, an influential bloc of deep-pocketed conservatives, the prize was not votes. It was money.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Afghan Policewomen Struggle Against Culture
articles.snippet: In a clash between Western ideals and Afghan realities, an effort to elevate the status of women by recruiting them to the police force has often backfired.
articles.abstract: In a clash between Western ideals and Afghan realities, an effort to elevate the status of women by recruiting them to the police force has often backfired.
articles.lead_paragraph: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Parveena almost got away.

articles.headline: Tyco’s ‘Piggy,’ Out of Prison and Living Small
articles.snippet: Convicted in 2005 of looting nearly $100 million from Tyco, L. Dennis Kozlowski was the face of Wall Street gluttony. Now a free man, he speaks for the first time of his more modest life.
articles.abstract: Convicted in 2005 of looting nearly $100 million from Tyco, L. Dennis Kozlowski was the face of Wall Street gluttony. Now a free man, he speaks for the first time of his more modest life.
articles.lead_paragraph: These days, his shower curtain is from Bed Bath & Beyond in a nondescript white.

articles.headline: Data Security Is Becoming the Sparkle in Bitcoin
articles.snippet: With the price of Bitcoin plummeting, the technology that stores the currency’s transactions is gaining value as a safe and open way to keep other kinds of records.
articles.abstract: With the price of Bitcoin plummeting, the technology that stores the currency’s transactions is gaining value as a safe and open way to keep other kinds of records.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some couples opt for a traditional wedding, while others go for the Elvis impersonator in Las Vegas. But David Mondrus and Joyce Bayo may be the first to have incorporated Bitcoin.

articles.headline: Industry Issues Intrude in ‘Blurred Lines’ Case
articles.snippet: While a copyright infringement case focuses on the sheet music version of a Robin Thicke hit, the trial raises questions about the music industry and one artist’s debt to another.
articles.abstract: While a copyright infringement case focuses on the sheet music version of a Robin Thicke hit, the trial raises questions about the music industry and one artist’s debt to another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before a special audience in Los Angeles last week, the velvet-voiced pop singer Robin Thicke performed his 2013 hit “Blurred Lines,” ran through a medley at the piano and discussed artistic inspiration.

articles.headline: Justice Department to Fault Ferguson Police, Seeing Racial Bias in Traffic Stops
articles.snippet: A Justice Department report will accuse the police in Ferguson, Mo., of making discriminatory traffic stops of African-Americans that created racial animosity leading up to an officer’s shooting of a black teenager, law enforcement officials said.
articles.abstract: A Justice Department report will accuse the police in Ferguson, Mo., of making discriminatory traffic stops of African-Americans that created racial animosity leading up to an officer’s shooting of a black teenager, law enforcement officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has nearly completed a highly critical report accusing the police in Ferguson, Mo., of making discriminatory traffic stops of African-Americans that created years of racial animosity leading up to an officer’s shooting of a black teenager last summer, law enforcement officials said.

articles.headline: Kerry Is Pushing for Agreement in Iran Nuclear Talks
articles.snippet: With so much at stake in the Iranian nuclear talks, Secretary of State John Kerry’s relentless negotiating style and repeated meetings with Iran’s foreign minister have become part of the debate.
articles.abstract: With so much at stake in the Iranian nuclear talks, Secretary of State John Kerry’s relentless negotiating style and repeated meetings with Iran’s foreign minister have become part of the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They have spent long hours alone together. They exchange private emails. Their walk along the Rhone River in Geneva in January so unnerved hard-line lawmakers in Tehran that they signed a petition fretting about the duo’s unseemly “intimacy.”

articles.headline: Wells Fargo Puts a Ceiling on Subprime Auto Loans
articles.snippet: Fearing increased risk and slipping standards, Wells Fargo will keep new subprime car loans to no more than 10 percent of its total auto loans.
articles.abstract: Fearing increased risk and slipping standards, Wells Fargo will keep new subprime car loans to no more than 10 percent of its total auto loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo, one of the largest subprime car lenders, is pulling back from that roaring market, a move that is being felt throughout the broader auto industry.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: China’s Long Food Chain Plugs In
articles.snippet: The country’s sprawling supply chain has challenged governmental efforts to ensure quality, and so its tech giants are working to provide shoppers with useful tools.
articles.abstract: The country’s sprawling supply chain has challenged governmental efforts to ensure quality, and so its tech giants are working to provide shoppers with useful tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The smartphone tells the story of a kiwi fruit in China.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Obama and Netanyahu Play Down Rancor on Iran, but Views Still Differ Sharply
articles.snippet: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel offered divergent approaches to Iran but tried to cool down the personal nature of any dispute.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel offered divergent approaches to Iran but tried to cool down the personal nature of any dispute.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel offered radically divergent approaches to the perils of a nuclear-armed Iran on Monday even as they tried to cool down the personal nature of a long-distance dispute that has inflamed relations between the United States and Israel for more than a month.

articles.headline: Etihad Airways’ Rapid Growth Frustrates Rivals
articles.snippet: How Etihad runs and is financed are central in a fight with airlines in the United States, which accuse Persian Gulf carriers of stealing passengers.
articles.abstract: How Etihad runs and is financed are central in a fight with airlines in the United States, which accuse Persian Gulf carriers of stealing passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABU DHABI — Emerging from the desert like some giant steel squid, the organic forms of Abu Dhabi’s new airport terminal are starting to take shape.
